title: DNA nightmare: ‘Why can’t he be the father?’
text:
Share on Twitter 
YESTERDAY, news.com.au exclusively reported the heartbreaking case of a man from NSW who has lost access to the child he believed was his daughter. 
DNA swab tests proved him not to be the biological father and the 11-month old girl was taken into state care, despite him wanting to keep her. 
The child’s mother had been found to be “unsuitable” for custody by the court and the man was awarded sole custody, but this was revoked after the DNA test results. 
It seemed so unfair that he would have his baby taken away, and many news.com.au readers were left asking: “Why can’t he foster the child?” 
Justin Dowd, partner at Watts McCray lawyers NSW and accredited specialist in Family Law, tells news.com.au he has a right to apply to the court to be the baby’s carer, but there are no guarantees he would succeed in the process. 
“In a sense, it is correct to say this man who has been de facto father has no rights; he has no automatic rights. The law gives priority and immediately recognition to biological parents. Personally, I think that’s appropriate. A non-biological person would need to make an application to the court — with which, of course there are no guarantees,” says Dowd. 
This application could be to become foster carer, for instance. 
“This man would have a right to put his hand up and make an application through the Family Law Act. He is a person with a genuine and legitimate interest in the child’s life. Proceedings after an application would vary; they would take weeks rather than months.” 
Are the odds stacked against him because he’s a man trying to take on the Family Court which is well known to show gender bias towards women? 
“As a matter of law, fathers don’t have fewer rights than mothers but as a matter of practice it’s something we certainly see,” says Dowd. 
“Sociologically we have an expectation children will be with the mother. There is an in-built prejudice about fathers having children, particularly if they’re not the biological parents.” 
WHAT’S NEXT FOR MIKE*? 
After his story was published, Mike says he was overwhelmed by the supportive comments and he’s not giving up his fight to care for the baby. But there’s been another development. 
“Unfortunately now, the mother has named another man as the potential biological father,” Mike tells news.com.au 
“I now have him and his family to contend with. I asked the biological family if they could include me in her life. They said no. I’ve told them I will fight. 
“My lawyer is applying for access at this point, until the biological father has been assessed.” 
HOW IS THE CARER DECIDED? 
“Wherever possible a child lives with the mother. However, in this case, the mother was found to have no attachment so it wasn’t found to be in the child’s best interest,” Dowd says. 
In this case, the mother has been asked if she can identify another potential biological father. And once the biological father has been established, he will be given parental rights. 
Importantly, if a mother is found to have no attachment or have drug issues at an initial custody hearing, that doesn’t mean she loses all rights to her child. 
“This would remain under constant review. If the mother has a drug problem and can show in a year’s time that she has that under control, parental supervision would be reassessed. She can, at any time say, ‘Can I have my baby back now please?’” 
“In complicated matters like this, it’s important to get the right advice, from people who are up to date with new developments in the law — and ask all the right questions even if they’re difficult.” 
*Names have been changed to protect identities. News.com.au has sighted court documents that verify this story.
